content.title: Lumbar Radiculopathy
content.summary: Lumbar radiculopathy is a condition caused by compression or irritation of lumbar nerve roots, resulting in radicular pain, sensory changes, and/or weakness in a dermatomal distribution. L4-L5 and L5-S1 disc herniations are most common. Diagnosis is clinical with MRI confirmation when needed. Most cases resolve with conservative management.
key_points: L5 and S1 radiculopathies account for ~90% of cases
Straight leg raise (SLR) sensitive for L5/S1; femoral stretch for L2-L4
Red flags: cauda equina syndrome, progressive weakness, saddle anesthesia
MRI indicated if symptoms persist >6 weeks, red flags, or considering surgery
80-90% improve with conservative treatment within 6-12 weeks
Surgery (discectomy) if severe/progressive deficit or failed conservative care
content.statement: Lumbar radiculopathy is dysfunction of a lumbar nerve root causing dermatomal pain, sensory loss, and/or myotomal weakness, most commonly from disc herniation, diagnosed clinically with provocative maneuvers and confirmed by MRI when surgery is considered.

explanation.intuition: Imagine a nerve root as a cable exiting the spine. When a bulging disc pinches this cable, the entire territory it supplies lights up with pain, numbness, or weakness. The L5 nerve controls ankle dorsiflexion - so when L5 is pinched, you get a foot drop and pain shooting down the lateral leg.
explanation.key_insight: The clinical localization is the key skill: each nerve root has specific motor, sensory, and reflex findings. L4 = knee extension + patellar reflex; L5 = ankle dorsiflexion + no good reflex; S1 = ankle plantarflexion + ankle reflex. Pain radiating past the knee suggests true radiculopathy.
explanation.technical_details: Disc herniation typically occurs posterolaterally, compressing the traversing root (L4-L5 disc compresses L5 root). Far lateral herniation compresses the exiting root (L4-L5 disc compresses L4 root). The SLR stretches L5/S1 roots and is positive if pain reproduced at 30-70° of elevation.

definitions_glossary.radiculopathy: Dysfunction of nerve root causing dermatomal pain and sensory/motor deficits
definitions_glossary.sciatica: Pain radiating along sciatic nerve distribution (L4-S3); often from L5/S1 radiculopathy
definitions_glossary.disc_herniation: Nucleus pulposus extrusion compressing neural structures
definitions_glossary.straight_leg_raise: SLR test; positive if leg elevation 30-70° reproduces radicular pain
definitions_glossary.femoral_stretch_test: Tests L2-L4 roots; pain with hip extension in prone position
definitions_glossary.crossed_SLR: Contralateral SLR reproducing ipsilateral pain; highly specific for disc herniation
definitions_glossary.dermatomal_distribution: Cutaneous sensory territory innervated by single nerve root
definitions_glossary.myotomal_weakness: Weakness of muscles innervated by single nerve root
definitions_glossary.cauda_equina_syndrome: Compression of cauda equina causing saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder dysfunction
definitions_glossary.foot_drop: Inability to dorsiflex foot; L5 radiculopathy or peroneal palsy
definitions_glossary.neurogenic_claudication: Leg pain with walking from lumbar stenosis; relieved by leaning forward
definitions_glossary.epidural_steroid_injection: ESI; anti-inflammatory delivered to epidural space
definitions_glossary.discectomy: Surgical removal of herniated disc material

pathophysiology.mechanism: Nerve root compression and/or inflammation from disc herniation or stenosis
etiologies: Disc herniation (most common in young adults)
Less common: tumor, infection, diabetic radiculoplexopathy

anatomy.far_lateral_herniation: Compresses exiting root (e.g., L4-L5 disc → L4 root)
anatomy.central_herniation: May cause bilateral symptoms or cauda equina syndrome

L4_radiculopathy.pain_sensory: Anterior thigh, medial leg to ankle

L5_radiculopathy.pain_sensory: Lateral thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of foot, great toe
L5_radiculopathy.motor: Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension (EHL), hip abduction

S1_radiculopathy.pain_sensory: Posterior thigh, posterior leg, lateral foot, plantar foot
S1_radiculopathy.motor: Ankle plantarflexion, toe flexion, hip extension

straight_leg_raise.technique: Supine; passive elevation of extended leg

femoral_stretch.technique: Prone; passive hip extension with knee flexed

red_flags: Night pain not relieved by rest

MRI.findings: Disc herniation, nerve root compression, stenosis

differential_diagnosis: Hip osteoarthritis (groin pain, limited internal rotation)
Piriformis syndrome (buttock pain, no back pain)
Vascular claudication (pulse deficits, relieved by standing still)

first_line: Short course oral steroids (controversial, may provide short-term relief)
adjuncts: Neuropathic pain medications (gabapentin, pregabalin) for persistent pain

epidural_steroid_injections.indication: Moderate-severe radicular pain not responding to conservative care
epidural_steroid_injections.efficacy: Short-term pain relief; limited evidence for long-term benefit

surgical_indications: Intractable pain despite 6-12 weeks conservative treatment

surgical_options.microdiscectomy: Standard procedure; good outcomes in properly selected patients

definition.@value: Dysfunction of a lumbar nerve root causing dermatomal pain, sensory changes, and/or myotomal weakness, most commonly from disc herniation

scopeNote.@value: Covers clinical localization by nerve root level, diagnostic approach, and conservative vs surgical management

learning_objectives: Localize lumbar radiculopathy to specific nerve root level
Perform and interpret straight leg raise and femoral stretch tests
Identify red flags requiring urgent evaluation
Determine indications for MRI and surgical referral
clinical_pearls: L5 = great toe extension + dorsiflexion; S1 = plantarflexion + ankle reflex
Crossed SLR is highly specific (88%) for disc herniation
Pain past the knee = more likely true radiculopathy vs referred pain
Cauda equina = EMERGENCY; check rectal tone, bladder function
80-90% improve conservatively - surgery reserved for specific indications
common_misconceptions: All back pain with leg radiation is radiculopathy - referred pain is common
MRI should be immediate - only needed for red flags or persistent symptoms
Disc herniation always needs surgery - most resolve conservatively

citations.authors: Kreiner DS, Hwang SW, Easa JE, et al.
citations.title: An evidence-based clinical guideline for the diagnosis and treatment of lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on NASS evidence-based clinical guidelines

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed.
NASS Clinical Guidelines for Lumbar Disc Herniation
